An open letter to those who complain about the content delivery:  Isn't it lucky that the information is being belied in a format where pausing, slowing down, and rewinding are all options? It isn't my intent to offend, but this video probably isn't exactly for you. That isn't to say crash course doesn't want as many people to enjoy their content as possible, but the original purpose was to be a resource for AP student. As someone who is currently in AP Physics and on this unit, this wasn't too fast. That's not to say that students are expected to catch everything just by watching it the first time through. But the students here are either watching it for a preview before class, an additional perspective, or a review before a test. No one is meant to walk away form crash course with a physics major. These are meant to be fast videos to give a basic understanding to curious internet goers and to help students learn and study.   Best wishes, Vicki

baby pancakes angular velocity is rate of change of angular displacement with respect to time.   Say a minute hand moves five minutes from 12 to 1. Hence, the angle displaced from 12 to 1  is: 1/12(360) = 30 degrees  So now we have angular displacement( the change in angle from a starting point, in this case the 12)   Since angular velocity = d(theta)/dt, where theta is the angular displacement which we have found (30 degrees),  we now need to find the time. So how long does it take for the minute hand to move from 12 to 1? (5mins=300seconds)   hence angular velocity , omega= rad/s  since 30 degrees is pi/6, therefore   angular velocity = (pi/6)/300secs

No, Newtonian physics does not work close to the speed of light.   As a simpler example, imagine two objects going towards each other at 2m/s. From the point of view of one of the objects, the other is moving at 4m/s. If the two objects were moving at 90% of the speed of light, you might expect one to appear to be moving 1.8 times the speed of light from the point of view of the other. However, this is not the case.

Two reasons why this isn't possible:  Firstly, to be able to move something at the speed of light that has mass is impossible, and even then to spin something even remotely close to it would require a ridiculously strong material as the centripetal acceleration would cause the whole spinny-thing to tear apart.  So instead of thinking about spinny-things, I'm going to take the much simpler case that is more feasible, but which looks at the same  question.  Imagine you have somehow constructed a hugely powerful spaceship that can travel at half the speed of light.  If this spaceship were to then fire a photon beam, would this beam of light be travelling at 1.5 times the speed of light relative to an observer away from the spaceship? It turns out no!  In fact, it is one of the Fundamental Laws of Physics that light always travels at the speed of light.  Always.  If you were to fire a beam of light and then were to travel beside it very close to the speed of light, it would still travel away from you at the speed of light!  This is such a remarkable fact that an entire new subject of Physics had to be invented to deal with it:  Special Relativity.  If you aren't aware of this bit of Physics I highly recommend looking into it, because it fundamentally changed the way we understood how the Universe works.  It has some pretty far-reaching effects, not least of which is that all of the Crash Course episodes so far aren't actually true!  (Well, they're actually very good approximations to reality for slow things.  As soon as you start travelling close to the speed of light, weird things happen to ensure that you don't go faster than the Cosmic Speed Limit.)  Such curious things include:  moving clocks slow down, moving rulers shrink, space and time aren't separate things but connected together into 'spacetime', and even the famous equation E=mc^2, saying that mass and energy are very much interlinked.  There's no way I can fully explain the ins and outs of Relativity in one comment (it normally takes a full College/University semester course on the subject to get a complete grip, and I've also missed some pretty major points).  If you're interested in all of this, then there a whole bunch of YouTube videos that can do a better job of explaining than I have.  I'm happy to recommend some videos etc. if you're interested.  I'll even make an educated guess that Crash Course Physics will have an episode on it, if you wait a while!

Physics isn't hard; it's confusing. You know what else is confusing? Most things. The key here is practice. Want to learn to solve anagrams? Solve anagrams. Want to learn to play guitar? Play guitar. Want to learn maths and physics? Do maths and physics.   If I were you I wouldn't worry about who dicovered and varified what, and if you are then wikipedia holds the answers.   In terms of derivation this is something that you will have to just accept not knowing much about to start off with, just as people accept that the corner shaped pieces of a puzzle must be placed in the corners. However, as you learn more and more about the subject you will be able to make connections, and slot in the rest of the pieces of the puzzle.   Physics is daunting above all else, and that's why a good teacher who will answer your questions is invaluable. If you don't know or are unsure you must be willing to ask for help. You must also be willing to give it a go, and learn from your mistakes (where you made them).     In answer to your question, no, a vacuum will have no effect. If you were trying to work out deceleration due to air resistance then it would, but for the maths behind rotation, no.   As a rule of thumb though don't try to over complicate things. My old physics teacher told us this: If someone asks you to calculate something about a cow, don't. Just calculate it for a sperical cow in a vacuum. ie: remove as many variables as possible and simplify the question as much as possible.

If you are decent at parametric equations (not needed actually, but it makes things organized), trigonometry and basic calculus, you can prove all the equations featured in this video. Assume that all orbital speed is constant.   All you need to know is that ω = θ/t = (2*π*r)/T, and that the position of a point i circular motion is described as [r*cos(ω*t), r*sin(ω*t)], where ω is angular velocity, θ is the angle measured relative to your starting position, t is time spent on this change, r is the distance between your point and the center of rotation and T is the period of this change (time spent making one revolution).   It's really fun working it out if you have the time.  If you're not familiar with trig. or calc., then I have no advice but to trust the equations. I had the same issue ("trusting" the equations) when learning physics, but my teacher told me to prove everything to my self (is difficult, understand the derivation). It helps to understand where witch equations should be used and practice your problem solving and mathematical skills. I wish you the best of luck!

Yes, your foot is moving relative to you, but to the floor? No it isn't. Physics is all about points of reference. Think of a bystander watching your foot as you walk. When you put your foot on the floor is the ground underneath your foot moving? No, it isn't, and if it is you're about to fall over or are ice skating. This means that your foot and the ground have a relative velocity of 0.   Think of it another way: if the bottom of a car tyre didn't have a relative velocity of 0 to the road then the tyre would be spinning faster than the car was moving along the ground, ie: doing a burnout and leaving a big 11 on the road.

We're talking about velocity relative to the road here, not to the car.   To use your own analogy: imagine watching the gum just before, as it does, and just after it touches the road in super slow motion. As the gum comes around the front of the tyre it will actually start slowing down until it touches the road. Freeze frame. Is the road moving underneath the gum? No it isn't. This means that the gum and the road are now moving at exactly the same speed.   Don't believe me? Try it out for yourself: get a glass (or anything cylindrical) and put a big blotch of ink from a whiteboard marker on it. Measure the diameter of the blotch. Now roll it over a piece of paper making sure that the glass isn't spinning without moving. Look at the blotch of ink it left behind on the paper. What size is it? It should be exactly the same size as the blotch on the glass. This is only possible if they had a relative velocity of 0. If the relative velocity was more or less than 0 there would be a streak of ink, as if you scraped the ink blotch along the paper.   Think of what would happen if they didn't have a relative velocity of 0: they would skid.    If we were talking about the velocity relative to the car then the horizontal velocity would change from +ive (at the top of the wheel) to 0 (at the left and right side) to -ive (at the bottom) to +ive etc. Vertical velocity would change from 0 (at the top and bottom) to -ive (on the right) to 0 to +ive on the left.
When your foot presses on the ground, it is not moving, but your body is. It is not until you push with your other foot that your original foot lifts off the ground and moves with you.

"isn't moving" is a misnomer.. "Isn't moving in relation to something else" makes more sense. Your whole body is moving but while your foot is planted, in relation to the ground your foot is not moving.  The whole of your body EXCEPT your foot is moving forward, but your body is pushing your foot 'backward' in relation to itself. Set a camera on the ground and record a car driving past. Watch it frame by frame. The car is rolling forward clearly, but the bottom point of the wheel is NOT moving in relation to the ground.  The top of the tire will have motion blur from moving forward twice as fast as the car, but the part touching the pavement will have zero velocity in relation to the ground (and the camera).

The wheel isn't slipping. It rolls by "grabbing" the ground via friction and rolling. Think of a guy walking. His foot hits the ground, and pushes the rest of his body forward. But his foot isn't moving when it's touching the ground. The foot only moves when he lifts his foot off the ground, during which another foot is on the ground ahead of it, not moving either. In the case of the wheel, once the part that was the bottom lifts off the ground, it's not "the bottom" anymore. So at any given point, the "bottom point" is not moving - the "bottom point" is always the foot that's on the ground, and when that point is lifted off the ground, the "bottom" is now another point.

Try to think of it this way: suppose the wheel is rolling forward (to the right). The wheel turns clockwise, from our perspective. As a point on the wheel closes in on the bottom of the wheel, its velocity vector that says it is moving around the center of the wheel points to the left. But the whole wheel (that point included) should also have a velocity vector directed to the right.  As a result of this, points that are in contact with the surface have a net velocity of the sum of -v_tangential and +v_translational. If the wheel is rolling "without slipping," those speeds should equal one another in magnitude, and cancel out when adding them.  This also means that points at the top of the wheel are moving with speed 2v, and the points on the far left and right of the wheel are moving along the horizontal axis with just speed v.  Did that clear it up?
